title: Landzicht Farm: Compositional Study

thumbnail.alt_text: A work made of fabricated charcoal on blue laid paper.

description: This drawing relates closely to a painting in the Gemeentemuseum in The Hague (25.1995) in both subject matter and style. However, it is nearly impossible to establish when the drawing was made or whether the drawing or painting came first. Prior to 1908, Piet Mondrian rarely dated his work; moreover, his artistic evolution is hard to trace chronologically since he made two kinds of work simultaneously: formally experimental landscapes and—forced by his meager finances to appeal to buyers—naturalistic scenes. Based on stylistic similarities to other works of that time, Robert Welsh, a scholar of Mondrian’s early work, dated the sheet to around 1905.
medium_display: Fabricated charcoal on blue laid paper
credit_line: Edward E. Ayer Endowment Fund in memory of Charles L. Hutchinson
publication_history:
Robert P Welsh, Piet Mondrian's Early Career: The "Naturalistic" Periods (New York, 1977), p. 83.

Lu Bro, Drawing: A Studio Guide (New York, 1978), p. 179, fig. 18.5.

Otto G. Ocvirk, Art Fundamentals: Theory and Practice (Dubuque, 1981) (ill.).

Yves-Alain Bois, "Mondrian Draftsman" Art in America, 69 (1981), p. 98 (ill.), as "Trees by the River Gein."

Robert Welsh and Joop Joosten, Piet Mondrian: Catalogue Raisonné I (Santa Barbara, Calif., 1996), p. 329, no. A435 (ill.).
exhibition_history:
New York, Wildenstein and Company, "Master Drawings from The Art Institute of Chicago," October 17-November 30, 1963, n.p., cat. 135, as "Trees by the River Gein," before 1908.

Chicago, Allan Frumkin Gallery, "Piet Mondrian: The Early Years 1905-1908," 1964  cat. 7.

Stuttgart, Germany, Staatsgalerie Stuttgart, "Mondrian: Zeichnungen, Aquarelle, New Yorker Bilder," December 6, 1980-February 15, 1981, cat. 18, as "Trees by the River Gein" 1905; traveled to The Hague, The Netherlands, Haags Gemeentemuseum, March 20-May 31, 1981; and the Baltimore Museum of Art, July 14-September 20, 1981, cat. 26.

The Art Institute of Chicago, "Bridget Riley Drawings: From the Artist's Studio", September 17, 2022 - January 16, 2023, p. 28, fig. 7 (ill.), cat. by Jay Clarke, et. al.
provenance_text: Johannes Samuel Fredericus Esser (1877-1946), Amsterdam, by 1912 [Joosten and Welsh 1996]; Esser estate, from 1946 [Joosten and Welsh 1996].   Sold by Allan Frumkin Gallery, New York, to the Art Institute, 1962.
